Description: Defines ice hockey playing surface as a "Rink".
Specifies rink size boards glass and logos.
Recommended rink dimensions of 60.96m x 30.48m maximum 60.96m x 25.91m minimum with 8.53m corner radius.
Boards to be 1.02-1.22m high with white surface facing ice and 30.48cm light-colored base plate.
Recommends glass or plexiglass mounted to boards to prevent pucks entering spectator areas.
Logos must not disrupt official ice markings; recommends no logos in end zones.
Describes all lines and zones on the ice surface.
Red goal line 5.08cm wide 3.35m from each end parallel to end boards.
Blue lines 30.48cm wide positioned based on rink length.
Red center line 30.48cm wide midway between goal lines.
Defines defending zone neutral zone and attacking zone.
Details goal specifications and installation.
Goals positioned in center of goal lines with stationary posts and nets.
Posts set 1.83m apart 1.22m high with crossbar; all 5.08cm in diameter.
Net of approved design attached to back of goal.
Goal frame painted red.
Defines the goal crease area.
Goal crease marked by 5.08cm red line.
Semi-circle of 1.82m radius with L-shaped markings in front corners.
Crease includes space outlined by lines and extends vertically to top of goal frame.
Describes center ice markings.
30.48cm blue spot in center with 4.57m radius circle marked by 5.08cm blue line.
Details neutral zone face-off spot positioning.
Two 60.96cm red spots in neutral zone 1.52m from each blue line.

Rule Name: End Zone Face-off Spots and Circles
Description: Describes end zone face-off spots and circles.

Rule Name: End Zone Face-off Spots and Circles
Description: Red spots and circles with specific dimensions and markings.

Rule Name: End Zone Face-off Spots and Circles
Description: Located 6.09m from goal lines and 6.71m from center of rink.

Rule Name: End Zone Face-off Spots and Circles
Description: Circles reduced in smaller rinks to maintain 60.96cm from boards.
Requirements for team benches.
Seats or bench for each team accommodating at least 14 players in neutral zone.
Gates should open away from ice.
Only uniformed players and maximum 5 team officials permitted on bench.
Team officials restricted to bench area during game.
Home team chooses end and corresponding bench for game start.
Requirements for penalty benches.
Separate area with seats for 8 people including penalized players and officials.
Gates should open away from ice; separate home and visitor benches.
When penalty gates are at unequal distances closer one is for visiting team.
Defines area in front of timekeeper for referees.
Semi-circular red line with 3.05m radius in front of timekeeper; players not allowed without direction.
Required timing and signaling equipment.
Sound device for timekeeper.
Clock visible to spectators players and officials.
Red light behind each goal for goal judge; recommends green light/buzzer for period end.
Requirements for team and official dressing rooms.
Suitable room with toilet and shower for visiting team.
Separate room with toilet and shower for officials.
No inappropriate discussions between team personnel and officials.
Only authorized league/member representatives allowed in officials' room.
Lighting requirements.
Rinks must be adequately lit for players and spectators.
Defines team composition limits.
Maximum 6 players on ice during play.
Maximum 5 team officials on bench including at least one Safety Person.
Rules for eligible players and team rosters.
Maximum 20 players in uniform (up to 18 skaters 2 goaltenders); minimum 6 to start.
Team officials must provide player list before game; visiting team lists first.
Penalty for false statements on game report.
Players must identify themselves when requested by referee.
Players must wear numbers at least 25.40cm high on back of jersey.
One goaltender allowed on ice; may be substituted for skater.
Only goaltenders permitted to wear goaltender equipment.
Alternate goaltender must take position immediately with no warm-up.
Pre-game warm-up restricted to own half of ice.
Penalties during warm-up served at start of game.
Maximum 20 players in warm-up; not necessarily on game report.
Suspended players not permitted in warm-up or on bench.
Injured players allowed on bench in minor/female hockey if wearing minimum equipment.
Duties and identification of team captains.
Each team may have captain and up to three alternates.
C and "A" must be worn visibly on jersey; approx. 7.62cm high.
Captains lose privileges while serving penalties.
Goaltenders or team officials cannot be captains/alternates.
Procedures for handling injured players.
Injured players must be replaced by substitutes.
Play continues until injured player's team gains possession; injured player must leave ice.
Injured goaltender must be replaced by alternate or player with goaltender privileges.
Player replacing goaltender must follow equipment rules.
For serious injuries referee may allow players to leave ice.
Injured penalized players may go to dressing room if replaced in penalty box.
Procedures for measuring equipment.
Equipment measurement done at referee's crease when requested by captain.
Complaining team penalized if measurement not sustained.
Only one measurement per stoppage.
Illegal equipment corrected without unnecessary delay.
Captain must specify which part of stick to measure.
No goals disallowed due to measurements.
Violations result in illegal equipment penalties.
Rules for broken or lost sticks.
Players must drop broken stick pieces immediately.
Players may only receive sticks from bench or teammates on ice.
Goaltenders may use player's stick until next stoppage.
Violations result in illegal equipment penalties.
Specifications for player and goaltender sticks.
Approved materials; no unauthorized modifications.
Player stick maximum 1.60m long blade 5.08-7.62cm wide.
Goaltender stick maximum 1.4m long with specific blade dimensions.
Shaft ends must be covered; hollow shafts need protective cap.
Tape of any color permitted.
Players may carry only one stick while playing.
Violations result in illegal equipment penalties.
Requirements for player skates.
All players must wear skates.
Hockey skates only; no speed or figure skates.
Only goaltenders may use goaltender skates.
Violations result in illegal equipment penalties.
Specifications for goaltender equipment.
Equipment for protection only; no additional stopping aids.
Pads maximum 27.94cm wide 96.52cm long minimum boot height 17.78cm.
Blocker maximum 20.3cm wide 38.1cm long; catching glove with specific measurements.
Chest/arm pad restrictions on ridges layering and dimensions.
Violations result in illegal equipment penalties.
Requirements for player protective gear.
All equipment except gloves headgear and goalie pads must be worn under uniform.
CSA-certified helmet and facial protector required properly fastened.
BNQ-certified throat protector required for minor and female hockey.
Players must replace lost protective equipment or leave ice.
Guidelines for facial protector types based on age and position.
Improper use of protective equipment results in penalties.
Prohibition of dangerous equipment.
Equipment likely to cause injury prohibited.
Modified equipment prohibited.
Non-standard equipment prohibited.
Elbow pads without soft covering prohibited.
Supplemental oxygen prohibited.
Team warning first then penalties for violations.
Official puck specifications.
Vulcanized rubber 2.54cm thick 7.62cm diameter 156-170g black.
Requirements for securing jerseys.
Junior/Senior players must wear secure jersey tie-down.
Overview of all penalty types.
Penalties may be assessed before during or after game.
Coach designates player from ice to serve team penalties.
Two-minute penalties resulting in shorthanded play.
Player except goaltender off ice for 2 minutes.
Minor penalty terminates if opposing team scores; double minor first penalty terminates.
Coincidental minors don't cause shorthanded situation.
Two-minute team penalties.
Team plays shorthanded for 2 minutes.
Coach designates player from ice to serve the penalty.
Five-minute penalties plus game misconduct.
Any major penalty includes automatic game misconduct; player ordered to dressing room.
Major penalty served before minor if both assessed.
Equal penalties to both teams at same stoppage.
Teams remain at full strength for coincidental penalties.
Differential in time penalties served by player from ice.
Penalized player serves all penalties in penalty box.
MOTO procedure for canceling penalties: Many One Take Order.
Special rules for coincidental minors in Junior.
Teams play 4-on-4 for single coincidental minors in Junior.
Time differential penalties served by substitute player.
Rule doesn't apply to major or match penalties.
Ten-minute non-time penalties.
Player serves 10 minutes but team doesn't play shorthanded.
Team places substitute in box for minor + misconduct.
Second misconduct results in game misconduct.
Removal from game penalties.
Game misconduct results in removal from game; 10 minutes recorded.
Game ejection assessed for accumulation of certain penalties.
Game misconduct in last 10 minutes results in automatic one-game suspension.
Severe misconduct resulting in removal.
Player/official ordered to dressing room; 10 minutes recorded.
If assessed in last 10 minutes results in automatic one-game suspension.
Five-minute time penalty plus removal for attempt to injure.
Player/official ordered to dressing room for balance of game.
Team sends player from ice to serve 5-minute time penalty.
Non-time penalties awarded in lieu of minors.
Awarded for various infractions including breakaway fouls.
Procedure for conducting penalty shots.
Penalties for interfering with penalty shot.
Penalty shot awarded even if time expires.
Player committing foul cannot take penalty shot.
No additional minor penalty if penalty shot awarded.
Stick measurement requests during penalty shots.
Goals awarded without being scored.
Awarded when defending team without goaltender commits penalty that would result in penalty shot.
Goaltender considered "substituted" after legal player change.
No assists given on awarded goals.
Special rules for goaltender penalties.
Any goaltender penalty served by player who was on ice.
Alternate goaltender replaces ejected goaltender.
Goaltender penalized for playing beyond center red line.
Rules for teams with multiple penalties.
Third penalty delayed until one expires when two players serving penalties.
Players with expired penalties remain in box until stoppage.
Players return in order of penalty expiry.
Penalties served in order of occurrence.
Not applicable to coincidental penalties.
Procedures for signaling and assessing penalties.
Play stopped immediately for penalty by team in possession.
Delayed penalty signal for team not in possession; goal cancels minor penalty.
Match penalties stop play immediately.
Captain helps identify penalized player if number not known.
Referee can correct penalty decision before play resumes.
Authority for appointing game officials.
Members may use two three or four-official systems.
Officials must be treated with courtesy by players and team officials.
Referee has full authority on disputed matters.
Officials appointed by requirements for regional/national events.
All referees under control of Member in their jurisdiction.
Officials must be impartial.
Duties of on-ice officials.
Officials are representatives of Hockey Canada or Member.
Referees call teams to ice remain until players exit.
Referees check equipment when requested.
Referees assess penalties according to rules.
Referees give final decision on disputed goals.
Referees verify off-ice officials before game.
Referees announce penalties goals assists to scorer.
Referees separate opposing players on penalty bench.
Referees check and sign game report.
Play stopped if official injured during play.
Teams agree on officials if appointed ones unavailable.
Referee appoints replacement for unavailable linesperson.
Linesperson performs referee duties if referee unable to continue.
In two-referee system both perform linesperson duties.
Specific duties of linespersons.
Stop play for various violations including offsides icings etc.
Report too many players violations at next stoppage.
Report certain minor bench minor or double minor infractions to referee.
Report major match or misconduct infractions to referee.
Provide information about incidents when asked by referee.
Duties of goal judges.
One goal judge behind each goal; not members of competing teams.
Goal judges remain in same position whole game.
Goal judges decide if puck entered goal; decision is goal or no goal.
Referee not required to consult goal judge if certain of call.
Duties of penalty timekeeper.
Records penalty time; informs penalized players of remaining time.
Signals referee if player leaves penalty box early.
Announces penalized player infraction and time when PA available.
Duties of game scorekeeper.
Obtains verified lineups from team officials before game.
Provides lineup to referee and notes rule compliance issues.
Records goals assists penalties on game report.
Announces goal scorer and assistants when PA available.
Advises referee of repeated penalties (misconduct stick infractions).
Signs game report has referee sign forwards to proper authority.
Duties of game timekeeper.
Records start/finish times and actual playing time.
Signals start/end of periods and overtimes.
Announces one minute remaining in each period.
Referee makes final decision on time disputes.
Rules for player substitutions.
Maximum 6 players on ice; changes allowed from players' bench.
Players leaving penalty box must return via ice.
Teams must place correct number on ice; visiting team places lineup first.
Referee controls line change procedure at stoppages.
Players stay at bench during scrums until referee signals change.
No line change after icing in select categories.
Procedures for conducting face-offs.
Players taking face-off positioned properly; other players 4.57m away.
No goaltender may participate in face-off.
No physical contact before face-off except playing puck after completion.
Ejection from face-off for violations; replacement required.
Minor penalty for second violation during same face-off.
No player changes after "false start" face-off.
Rules determining where face-offs occur.
Center ice face-offs only at start of periods after goals or specific situations.
For non-penalty stoppages face-off at nearest spot to puck.
Penalties result in face-off in offending team's defending zone with exceptions.
Neutral zone face-offs conducted at spots nearest blue line; specific rules for violations.
End-zone face-off locations determined by specific scenarios.
Special face-off rules for Junior/Senior.
Defending team can't change lines after unintentional puck out of play.
Attacking team chooses face-off location after icing or penalty.
Violation procedures after icing in Junior.
First violation results in warning.
Subsequent violations on same stoppage result in minor penalty.
Rules for scoring and crediting goals.
Goal scored when puck completely crosses goal line.
Goal credited to last attacking player if defender puts in own net.
No goal if puck kicked or deliberately directed with body part.
Goal allowed if deflected off attacking player.
No goal if puck deflects directly off official into net.
Goal legal if puck propelled into crease before scoring.
Maximum two assists per goal recorded.
Rules for icing violations.
Icing called when team shoots puck from own half across opposing goal line.
No icing if team is shorthanded.
Exceptions to icing including if opposing player could play puck.
No line change after icing in specified categories.
Hybrid icing rules for higher categories.
Handling spectator interference with play.
Play stopped if spectator holds/interferes with player.
Play stopped if objects thrown on ice.
Rules for playing puck above shoulder height.
Play stopped if team contacts puck above shoulder height and gains possession.
No goal scored by high-sticking puck except in own goal.
High-sticking that contacts opponent penalized under Head Contact.
Junior/Senior high-sticking rules.
Play stopped if team contacts puck above shoulder height and gains possession.
No goal scored by high-sticking except in own goal.
High-sticking that contacts opponent penalized under High-Sticking.
No goal if puck contacted above crossbar by attacking player.
Rules for kicking the puck.
Kicking permitted in all zones.
No goal can result from attacking player kicking puck.
No goal if attacking player kicks object that propels puck into goal.
Rules for off-side violations.
Player off-side when both skates cross blue line before puck.
Delayed off-side procedure if players precede puck into zone.
Exceptions where player not considered off-side.
Intentional off-side results in defensive zone face-off.

Rule Name: Puck Out of Bounds or Unplayable
Description: Procedures when puck leaves play.

Rule Name: Puck Out of Bounds or Unplayable
Description: Face-off when puck goes out of bounds or becomes unplayable.

Rule Name: Puck Out of Bounds or Unplayable
Description: Penalty for deliberately putting puck out of play.

Rule Name: Puck Out of Bounds or Unplayable
Description: Play continues if puck quickly removed from back of net.

Rule Name: Puck Out of Bounds or Unplayable
Description: Penalty to goaltender who deliberately freezes puck on netting.

Rule Name: Puck Out of Sight and Illegal Puck
Description: Handling invisible or illegal pucks.

Rule Name: Puck Out of Sight and Illegal Puck
Description: Play stopped when referee loses sight of puck.

Rule Name: Puck Out of Sight and Illegal Puck
Description: Play continues if second puck appears unless it interferes with play.
Rules when puck hits official.
Play continues if puck touches official except if entering net or exiting play.
Procedures for starting game and periods.
Game starts at scheduled time; no delays for ceremonies without consent.
Face-off at center ice starts each period and after goals.
Only players taking face-off allowed on ice at period start.
Overtime procedures.
10-minute sudden-victory period then 20-minute period if needed.
Penalties remain in effect for overtime.
Teams refusing to play overtime follow Refusing to Start Play rule.
Regulation time and timeout rules.
Three 20-minute periods with 10-minute intermissions.
Team with most goals is winner.
Teams change ends each period; ice resurfaced between periods.
Unusual delays near period end may trigger early intermission.
Each team allowed one 30-second timeout during game.

Rule Name: Attempt to Injure or Deliberate Injury
Description: Penalties for intentionally causing harm.

Rule Name: Attempt to Injure or Deliberate Injury
Description: Double minor for minimal violence actions like hair pulling grabbing facial protector head-butting.

Rule Name: Attempt to Injure or Deliberate Injury
Description: Major and game misconduct for higher degree of violence or resulting injury.

Rule Name: Attempt to Injure or Deliberate Injury
Description: Match penalty for deliberate attempt to or actual injury of opponent.

Rule Name: Attempt to Injure or Deliberate Injury
Description: No misconduct penalty for attempt to injure.

Rule Name: Attempt to Injure or Deliberate Injury
Description: No game misconduct for attempt to injure.

Rule Name: Attempt to Injure or Deliberate Injury
Description: Team officials receive gross misconduct for head-butting attempts.
Penalties for dangerous checks into boards.
Minor for checking defenseless player into boards.
Major and game misconduct based on violence of impact or if injury results.
Match penalty for deliberate attempt to injure by boarding.
No misconduct penalty for boarding.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Rules for divisions where body-checking prohibited.
Minor for intentional body-check in U13 female hockey and other specified divisions.
Major and game misconduct based on impact violence or if injury results.
Match penalty for deliberate attempt to injure by body-checking.
No misconduct penalty for body-checking.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Penalties for excessive speed or distance before contact.
Minor for charging; includes blindside hits.
Major and game misconduct based on violence of impact or if injury results.
Match penalty for charging player unable to defend or deliberate injury attempt.
No misconduct penalty for charging.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Penalties for hits from behind.
Minor and game misconduct for intentional check from behind.
Major and game misconduct based on violence or if injury results.
Match penalty for check from behind into boards/goal or deliberate injury attempt.
No misconduct penalty for checking from behind.
Game misconduct when minor or major penalty assessed.
Penalties for contact to head face or neck in minor/female hockey.
Minor for accidental contact; double minor for intentional contact. Three minors results in game ejection.
Major and game misconduct based on violence or if injury results.
Match penalty for hit preventing self-defense or deliberate injury attempt.
No misconduct penalty for head contact.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Head contact rules for junior/senior divisions.
Minor and misconduct for head contact with moderate violence.
Major and game misconduct for high degree of violence or resulting in head injury.
Match penalty for hit preventing self-defense or deliberate injury attempt.
Misconduct penalty when minor penalty assessed.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Penalties for making contact with the knee.
Double minor for kneeing.
Major and game misconduct based on violence or if injury results.
Match penalty for deliberate attempt to injure by kneeing.
No misconduct penalty for kneeing.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Penalties for unnecessary rough play.
Minor for unnecessary rough play or contact after whistle.
Major and game misconduct based on violence or if injury results.
Match penalty for deliberate attempt to injure by roughing.
No misconduct penalty for roughing.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Penalties for fighting and related actions.
Minor for goaltender leaving crease during fight.
Major and game misconduct for fighting.
Match penalty for fighting with rings/tape/material to gain advantage.
Misconduct for not returning to bench during fight.
Game misconduct for joining fight or acting as peacemaker.
Gross misconduct for fighting with team official.
Additional penalties for starting or continuing fights.
Minor for instigator or aggressor in fight.
No major penalty for instigator/aggressor.
No match penalty for instigator/aggressor.
No misconduct penalty for instigator/aggressor.
No game misconduct penalty for instigator/aggressor.
Penalties for restraining opponent's movement.
Minor for holding opponent or opponent's stick.
Major and game misconduct if injury results.
No match penalty for holding.
No misconduct penalty for holding.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Penalties for impeding with stick in pulling motion.
Minor for hooking or butt-end hooking.
Major and game misconduct if injury results.
No match penalty for hooking.
No misconduct penalty for hooking.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Penalties for impeding player without puck.
Minor for various interference actions including goaltender contact.
Major and game misconduct based on violence or if injury results.
Match penalty for deliberate attempt to injure by interference.
No misconduct penalty for interference.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Penalties for bench personnel interfering with play.
Bench minor and game misconduct for interference from bench.
Major and game misconduct based on violence or resulting injury.
Match penalty for deliberate attempt to injure.
No misconduct penalty for interference from bench.
Game misconduct in most situations under this rule.
Gross misconduct for team officials who commit interference.
Penalties for impeding goaltender movement.
Minor for physical contact with goaltender.
Major and game misconduct based on violence or for charging goaltender.
Match penalty for deliberate attempt to injure goaltender.
No misconduct penalty for goaltender interference.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Penalties for causing opponent to fall.
Minor for tripping.
Major and game misconduct if injury results.
No match penalty for tripping.
No misconduct penalty for tripping.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Penalties for low hits below opponent's hips.
Minor for clipping.
Major and game misconduct based on violence or if injury results.
Match penalty for deliberate attempt to injure by clipping.
No misconduct penalty for clipping.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Penalties for taking opponent's feet out from under them.
Double minor for slew-footing.
No major penalty for slew-footing.
Match penalty based on violence of impact or if injury results.
No misconduct penalty for slew-footing.
No game misconduct penalty for slew-footing.
Penalties for jabbing with stick shaft end.
Double minor for attempt or minimal violence butt-end.
No major penalty for butt-ending.
Match penalty based on violence or if injury results.
No misconduct penalty for butt-ending.
No game misconduct penalty for butt-ending.
Penalties for checking with stick shaft between hands.
Minor for cross-checking.
Major and game misconduct based on violence or if injury results.
Match penalty for deliberate attempt to injure.
No misconduct penalty for cross-checking.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Penalties for hitting opponent with stick.
Minor for slashing or attempted slashing.
Major and game misconduct based on violence or if injury results.
Match penalty for deliberate attempt to injure by slashing.
No misconduct penalty for slashing.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Penalties for jabbing with stick blade tip.
Double minor for attempt or minimal violence spear.
No major penalty for spearing.
Match penalty for forceful spearing or if injury results.
No misconduct penalty for spearing.
No game misconduct penalty for spearing.
Penalties for carrying stick above shoulders in Junior/Senior.
Minor for contacting opponent above shoulder with stick; double minor for accidental injury.
No major penalty for high-sticking (use Head Contact rule).
No match penalty for high-sticking (use Head Contact rule).
No misconduct penalty for high-sticking.
No game misconduct penalty for high-sticking.
Penalties for deliberately delaying play.
Minor or bench minor for various delay tactics; penalty shot possible in certain circumstances.
No major penalty for delay except under Refusing to Start Play.
No match penalty for delay of game.
No misconduct penalty for delay of game.
No game misconduct penalty for delay of game.

Rule Name: Handling or Falling on the Puck
Description: Penalties for illegal puck handling.

Rule Name: Handling or Falling on the Puck
Description: Play stopped for hand pass; minor for closing hand on puck or falling on puck; penalty shot if in crease.

Rule Name: Handling or Falling on the Puck
Description: No major penalty for handling puck.

Rule Name: Handling or Falling on the Puck
Description: No match penalty for handling puck.

Rule Name: Handling or Falling on the Puck
Description: No misconduct penalty for handling puck.

Rule Name: Handling or Falling on the Puck
Description: No game misconduct penalty for handling puck.
Penalties for exaggerating or simulating fouls.
Minor for unsportsmanlike conduct for diving/embellishment.
No major penalty for diving.
No match penalty for diving.
No misconduct penalty for diving.
No game misconduct penalty for diving.

Rule Name: Leaving the Players' or Penalty Bench
Description: Penalties for illegal bench exits.

Rule Name: Leaving the Players' or Penalty Bench
Description: Minor for leaving penalty bench early or illegally; bench minor for team officials entering ice.

Rule Name: Leaving the Players' or Penalty Bench
Description: No major penalty for leaving bench.

Rule Name: Leaving the Players' or Penalty Bench
Description: No match penalty for leaving bench.

Rule Name: Leaving the Players' or Penalty Bench
Description: No misconduct penalty for leaving bench.

Rule Name: Leaving the Players' or Penalty Bench
Description: Game misconduct for leaving bench during fight; coach penalized if team leaves bench.

Rule Name: Leaving the Players' or Penalty Bench
Description: Gross misconduct for returning to ice after ejection/misconduct.

Rule Name: Throwing or Shooting Stick or Object
Description: Penalties for throwing equipment.

Rule Name: Throwing or Shooting Stick or Object
Description: Minor for throwing objects; penalty shot when thrown at puck/player in defending zone.

Rule Name: Throwing or Shooting Stick or Object
Description: Major and game misconduct if injury results.

Rule Name: Throwing or Shooting Stick or Object
Description: Match penalty for deliberate attempt to injure.

Rule Name: Throwing or Shooting Stick or Object
Description: Misconduct for throwing equipment out of playing area.

Rule Name: Throwing or Shooting Stick or Object
Description: Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Penalties for non-compliant equipment.
Minor for various equipment violations; bench minor for team captain violations.
No major penalty for illegal equipment.
No match penalty for illegal equipment.
Misconduct for various equipment violations including refusing measurement.
No game misconduct penalty for illegal equipment.
Gross misconduct for refusing to correct dangerous equipment or removing helmet during fight.
Penalties for excess players on ice.
Bench minor for too many players; penalty shot if deliberate in last two minutes.
No major penalty for too many players.
No match penalty for too many players.
No misconduct penalty for too many players.
No game misconduct penalty for too many players.
Penalties for team refusal to play.
No minor penalty; officials should use warnings then delay of game before this rule.
Major and game misconduct to coach who returns after being ordered to; penalty shot in last two minutes.
No match penalty for refusing to start play.
No misconduct penalty for refusing to start play.
Game misconduct when major penalty assessed.
Penalties for disrespectful behavior.
Minor or bench minor for unsportsmanlike actions.
No major penalty for unsportsmanlike conduct.
No match penalty for unsportsmanlike conduct.
Misconduct for persisting in conduct distraction during penalty shot or other specific actions.
Game misconduct for continued unsportsmanlike conduct after minor or misconduct.
Penalties for targeted profane or threatening conduct.
Bench minor for team official or unidentified player using abusive conduct.
No major penalty for abusive behavior.
No match penalty for abusive behavior.
Misconduct for player using abusive conduct.
Game misconduct for persistent abuse or team official abuse.
Gross misconduct for actions making travesty of game.
Penalties for spitting at individuals.
No minor penalty for spitting.
No major penalty for spitting.
Match penalty for deliberately spitting at any individual.
No misconduct penalty for spitting.
No game misconduct penalty for spitting.
Penalties for discriminatory taunts or conduct.
Gross misconduct for taunts based on race religion gender sexual orientation etc.
Penalties for physical confrontation with officials.
No minor penalty for official harassment.
No major penalty for official harassment.
Match penalty for threatening applying force to or injuring an official.
No misconduct penalty for official harassment.
Game misconduct for accidental contact with official during altercation.
